string.text: The 7.62x39mm intermediate rifle cartridge was designed by N.M. Elizarov and B.V. Semin in 1943. The cartridge is known coloquially as the M43, and sometimes called ".30 Short Russian" in the US. 7.62 FMJ (57-N-231) denotes a bullet with a heat-treated steel core. The round can punch through a steel helmet at up to 900 meters and pierce standard body armor at up to 600 meters. At 100 meters, the round can destroy 12-15cm-thick brick wall. The bullet has no distinctive color.

The 7.62x39mm intermediate round with an armor-piercing bullet (7N23). Developed in the late 1990s by D.I. Veronskiy and V.V. Zakharyaschev, and adopted by the Russian military in 2002. This new round has over three times the penetrative power of the FMJ round, while retaining the FMJ round's trajectory. It can penetrate a Russian 6B5 vest at up to 250 meters. At 100 meters, the round can destroy 12-15cm-thick brick wall. The bullet has a black tip for identification.

The 7.62x39mm intermediate round with an armor-piercing incendiary bullet (57-BZ-231) is designed to defeat lightly-armored targets at distances up to 300 meters. The bullet ignites after penetration of body armor or thick walls. It can punch through a steel helmet at up to 1100 meters and pierce standard body armor at up to 1000 meters. The round can also pierce 7mm-thick hardened steel at up to 200 meters. The bullet has a black tip with a red belt.

The 7.62x39mm M43 subsonic cartridge "US" (57-N-231U). The bullet features a weighted steel core, and is designed to be fired with a silencer/flash suppressor. Can penetrate a steel helmet at up to 400 meters and penetrate standard body armor at up to 75 meters. The bullet has a black tip with a green belt.

5.45x39mm low-recoil intermediate rifle cartridge. The small-caliber bullet provides a flatter trajectory, increasing its effective range. The round's disadvantages include lower blunt stopping power (although the bullet has a great tendency to yaw), and its tendency to ricochet. 5.45x39mm EPR (7N10) denotes enhanced penetration, with a heat-treated steel core. Standard in the Russian and Ukrainian armies since 1992, replacing the 7N6 and 7N6M. The bullet is lacquer-coated and has no distinctive color.

5.45x39mm low-recoil intermediate rifle cartridge with an armor-piercing bullet (7N22), designed to penetrate advanced body armor and light vehicles. The bullet can penetrate a 6mm-thick armor plate (standard for modern body armor) at up to 250 meters with 80% reliability. The bullet is lacquer-coated and has a black tip.

5.56x45mm/.223 Rem low-recoil intermediate rifle cartridge with a full-metal jacket (FMJ). Based on the .223 Remington hunting cartridge, the SS109 bullet, designed by Fabrique Nationale in Belgium, was adopted by NATO in the mid-1980s under index STANAG 4172.
5.56x45mm NATO low-recoil intermediate rifle cartridge with a armour piercing bullet, was designed to penetrate advanced body armor and light vehicles.

7.62ı54mmR rifle cartridge was developed in 1891 as a munition for the Mosin rifle. After modernization in 1930 the cartridge received the M1908/30 designation. When the SVD was developed the cartridge was modernized to improve accuracy and power at which it was designated 7N1. Full-metal jacket with no specific coloring.

7.62ı54mmR 7N26 AP armor-piercing rifle cartridge. In 1990 there was a modernization program for 7.62x54mmR cartridges. In 1998 standard 7N13 cartridge was improved with cone metal core and in 1999 new 7N26 cartridge was stated as standard armour-piercing munition. 7N26 armor-piercing cartridges has no specific label, cartridge pack is labeled with black line.

7.62ı54mmR 7N14 AP armor-piercing sniper rifle cartridge. In 1990 there was a modernization program for 7.62x54mmR cartridges. One of the goals was to improve piercing ability for bullet. 7N14 sniper rifle cartridge has improved piercing ability and accuracy.

Pistol unitary cartridge caliber 7, 62x25 mm TT mod. 1930. The basis for it was the 7.63 mm Mauser cartridge, which in turn originated from the 7.65 mm Borchardt cartridge of the 1893 model and is related to the 9 mm Luger created on the basis of the same cartridge. It is notable as the first pistol cartridge officially adopted for full service in Russia/USSR. Simple core, shell bullet.
Pistol unitary cartridge caliber 7. 62x25 mm TT mod. 1930, equipped with a bullet with a steel core. Improved armor-piercing ability of the bullet.

The 9x18 mm PM pistol unitary cartridge was created by B. V. Semin in 1951 to replace the 7.62 x 25 mm TT cartridge. Increasing the caliber to 9 mm allowed to maintain the stopping action with almost a twofold reduction in muzzle energy, which makes it possible to use a simpler automatic weapon. The cartridge case is a bimetallic, standard shell bullet, with a steel mushroom-shaped core pressed into a lead jacket. This solution saves lead and increases the penetration capacity of the bullet in relation to non-metallic obstacles, but when it hits the metal, the shell is destroyed, and the core bounces off the obstacle due to its shape, so the standard bullet of the 9x18 mm PM cartridge is not able to penetrate the army bulletproof vest.

The 9x18 mm PMM pistol unitary cartridge is an upgrade of the PM cartridge aimed at increasing the bullet's penetration capacity. In the cartridge, the powder charge is increased by 30% and a new bullet in the form of a truncated cone is applied. The result is increased muzzle velocity, its kinetic energy and, consequently, penetration and stopping power, and thanks to the new bullet form decreased the probability of ricochets. At a distance of up to 10 meters, the bullet of the PMM cartridge penetrates the army bulletproof vest.

The 9x19 mm Luger/Parabellum pistol unitary cartridge was created in 1902 by the German gunsmith Georg Luger. After the Second World War, the cartridge was adopted in many countries of the world as a standard NATO cartridge. Currently, this cartridge is one of the most common and mass-produced 9-mm cartridges for pistols and submachine guns, it is produced by a large number of manufacturers in different countries of the world. Production of commercial 9x19 mm cartridges in Russia was started in the 1990s. At the turn of the 2000s, it was decided to switch to a new standard 9x19 mm cartridge.

Pistol unitary cartridge caliber 9x19 mm +P + increased power. High speed and design features of the bullet ensure penetration of bulletproof vests of the 2nd class or 8-mm steel plate at a distance of at least 20 m.

Pistol unitary cartridge caliber .45 ACP (eng. Automatic Colt Pistol, .45 caliber-automatic pistol Colt caliber 0.45 inches, or 11, 43x23 mm) was created by John Browning in 1905. Since then, it has been a popular cartridge for self-defense (especially in the United States). The cartridge has a low muzzle velocity, and therefore it is often used to create "silent" versions of weapons with silencers. .45 ACP has almost the highest stopping action among modern pistol cartridges with acceptable dimensions and power available for use in silent weapons.

Pistol unitary cartridge caliber .45 ACP (Eng. Automatic Colt Pistol, .45 caliber-automatic pistol Colt caliber 0.45 inches, or 11, 43x23 mm) with improved performance, the so-called "Hydroshock". The expansive bullet has an increased stopping effect.
An empty pack of bullets .50 AE.

Pistol unitary cartridge caliber .50 AE (English Action Express, .50 caliber ó caliber 0.5 inches,or 12.7 x 33 mm) was created by Evan Wilding (company Action Arms) for IMI (Israel Military Industry). One of the most powerful pistol ammunition in the world.
12-gauge hunting cartridge, loaded with buckshot. At close distances, it has a huge killing effect. It is most effective at ranges up to 30 meters.

Hunting cartridge 12 gauge with a heavy shell-less bullet Jacana (the Jacques). It is usually used for hunting large animals, but it is also suitable for other purposes. Fairly accurate combat is facilitated by convex guide ribs, which give the bullet a rotational movement in flight. Effective at ranges up to 100 meters.
12-gauge hunting bullet cartridge. The bullet has a lead head and a plastic stabilizer, which has a positive effect on accuracy. Effective at ranges up to 150 meters.

Special cartridge 9x39 mm caliber machine-gun, armour-piercing. Developed with the aim of reducing the cost of the SP-5/SP-6, but serial purchases were limited to only a few batches due to low accuracy rates. Currently prohibited for use, as it creates a higher pressure in the barrel, which reduces the life of the weapon.

Special cartridge of 9x39 mm caliber sniper, with increased penetration. The bullet of the SP-6 cartridge can penetrate 8 mm steel sheet at a distance of 100 m or hit a target protected by a bulletproof vest of 2-3 protection classes at a distance of up to 300-400 meters.

Sniper cartridge caliber 12, 7x108 mm (7H34). Provides defeat of the manpower equipped with means of individual armor protection, unarmored and lightly armored ground and low-flying equipment at a distance of up to 1500 m. Armor-piercing effect of bullets on the armor plate of the 2P brand with a thickness of 10 mm at a range of 627 meters to 899 meters - at least 80%. Accuracy: at 300 m - 85 mm, at 1000 m ñ 700 mm.

Cartridge with armor-piercing incendiary bullet caliber 12, 7x108 mm (57-BZ-542). Provides defeat of lightly armored targets, manpower and firepower located behind light shelters, as well as low-flying equipment at a distance of up to 1500 m. Armor-piercing effect of bullets on armor plate with a thickness of 20 mm at a range of 100 meters - not less than 90%. The incendiary effect of bullets on gasoline located behind an armored plate with a thickness of 15 mm. at a range of 70 meters - not less than 75%.
Crossbow bolt with a plastic tail and a steel tip.
Aluminum shaft with plastic fins and a special tip with a fast-acting stunner.

40mm VOG-25 fragmentation rounds (7P17). The grenade is standalone and is caseless (propellant with primer is located on the rear of the grenade). During firing, the propellant powder gases continue to burn after the grenade leaves the launcher barrel, serving as an afterburner to increase trajectory while also lowering recoil slightly.

40mm VOG-25 fragmentation rounds ("Jump" modernized, 7P45). The main difference from the VOG-25 is the use of the VGM-P fuse, which has a bounding charge, allowing the grenade to explode in mid-air, or after crushing through cover. Provides a 50% increase in lethality.

40mm VG-40TB thermobaric, multipurpose rounds. The round acts as both a fragmentation round and a high explosive/incendiary round, and was designed to defeat targets in confined shelters, behind natural barriers, and inside light vehicles.
40 mm shot with M406 series fragmentation grenade for NATO standard grenade launchers (M79, M203, HK79, AG36, FN EGLM, FN GL1).

Manual light and sound grenade "Zarya-2". It is intended for temporary suppression of psycological stability of the opponent. The main impact factors are the bright flash of light and the loud sound of the explosion, which lead to temporary blindness and deafening of persons in the immediate vicinity of the center of the explosion, which for some time makes it impossible for them to provide effective resistance. It is used in special operations to capture criminals, stop mass riots, in the security alarm system, etc. It is fire-safe and shatter-free with a safe distance of 2 m. The effective range is 10 m. The disorientation effect can last from a few seconds to several minutes; the blinding time can reach 20-30 seconds; the hearing loss time can reach several hours.

The hand grenade of irritating action CS is equipped with a rapidly disintegrating stifling effect, which also affects the skin. CS has a smell that resembles the smell of mustard gas. The design of the grenade ensures its rotation during the formation of a cloud of irritant, which prevents the possibility of its reverse casting. Affects the area for 1-3 minutes.

RDG-M hand smoke grenade. Provides a smoke screen, the density of which reduces the field of view of the enemy and reduces its mobility, which increases the safety of personnel and contributes to the effective performance of their tasks. The length of the smoke screen is more than 10 m., the time of setting the curtain is 2 s., the duration of the curtain is more than 15 s.

Defensive hand grenade F-1 (57-G-721). Developed by designer F. I. Khrameev in 1939 on the basis of the French grenade F.1 Lemon systems. It is still in service with the Russian Army and the CIS countries. The radius of continuous damage by shrapnel is 7 m., the most likely damage is 30 m.

Offensive hand grenade RGD-5 (hand grenade remote, 57-G-717). The RGD-5 grenade was adopted by the Soviet Army in 1954 and is still in service with the Russian Army and the CIS countries. The radius of lethal action of fragments is up to 25 m.

ï %c[default]VOG-25 rounds
%c[255,1,255,255]ï %c[default]VOG-25PM rounds
%c[255,1,255,255]ï %c[default]VG-40TB rounds
 
The GP-25 "Bonfire" (6G15) is a 40mm muzzle-loaded, rifled grenade launcher. Designed by V.N. Telesh and adopted by the Soviet Armed Forces in 1978. It is designed to be mounted on Kalashnikov assault rifles, and can be used to defeat targets in fortifications, in trenches, and on reverse slopes. Has an effective range from 100-400 meters. The complete equipment set comes with a rubber buttplate (mounted to the rifle's stock), and a special return spring guide with a receiver cover catch (for use on early-production rifles). 
It is not recommended to mount grenade launchers on rifles with mounted optics and/or silencers due to violent recoil.

%c[255,1,255,255]Ammunition type: %c[default] \n%c[255,1,255,255]ï %c [default] M406 shot \n M203 grenade launcher for NATO rifles. This world's first mass-produced under-barrel grenade launcher was developed in the period 1967-1968 by the American corporation AAI as a replacement for the M79 hand grenade launcher. Unlike its predecessor, the M203 is mounted under the barrel and the shooter has the ability, depending on the situation, to fire both 40-mm grenades and automatic cartridges. The sight on the M203 is mounted on top of the launcher, which can interfere with aiming from a rifle, to solve this problem, the sight was made foldable. The grenade launcher was mounted with the help of tools by replacing the forearm of the M16 assault rifle with the casing of the M203 case. The Rail Interface System for various types of small arms is manufactured by Knight's Armament Co. Later, the M203PI EGLM (Enhanced Grenade Launcher Module) model from RM-Equipment Ink was introduced. modified for mounting on a Picatinny-type under-barrel guide and with a special mount included, allowing it to be mounted on various types of rifles.

%c[255,1,255,255]Ammunition type: %c[default] \n%c[255,1,255,255]ï %c [default] shot M406 \ nThe AG36 grenade launcher was developed in the late 1990s by the German company Heckler und Koch, mass-produced since 2000. To reload, the breech of the barrel is tilted to the left, which allows you to charge it with shots with long warheads, for example," non-lethal " grenades with tear gas). The grenade launcher is mounted by replacing the forearm of the HK G36 assault rifle with the AG36 casing. A special detachable stock has been developed that allows the grenade launcher to be used as a separate weapon. The AG36 is also adapted to the British Enfield L85A2. The AG36 variant, modified for installation on a Picatinny-type under-barrel guide, is offered under the designation AG-C/EGLM (Enhanced Grenade Launcher Module) as a replacement for the M203.

%c[255,1,255,255]Ammunition type: %c[default] \n%c[255,1,255,255]ï %c [default] shot M406 \ nThe GL1 grenade launcher was developed in the late 1990s by the Belgian company Fabrique Nationale Herstal specifically for use in conjunction with the FN Herstal F2000 modular rifle and grenade launcher. The grenade launcher is installed instead of the removable F2000 handguard.

%c[255,1,255,255]Ammunition type: %c[default] \n%c[255,1,255,255]ï %c[default] 9x19 mm Para-main \n%c[255,1,255,255]ï %c[default] 9x19 mm +P+ - high power \ psamozaryadny pistol caliber 9x19 mm Beretta 92FS. The model 92F of the Italian company Fabbrica D'armi Pietro Beretta spa in 1985 replaced the standard pistol "M9 pistol, 9 mm" of the US Army. Modified for shooting with reinforced cartridges, the 92FS has been in service with the US Army since 1989, becoming one of the most common and recognizable pistols in the world. Various modifications are made both in Italy and in other countries, including the United States, and are in service with the army, police and special forces of many countries. Despite the serious dimensions and weight, the Beretta is easy to handle, has a relatively high accuracy, thanks to a fairly powerful cartridge and a capacious magazine, they are well-deserved popularity in the civilian weapons market, as well as among representatives of the criminal world.

%c[255,1,255,255]Ammunition:
ï %c[default]7.62x39mm FMJ
%c[255,1,255,255]ï %c[default]7.62x39mm AP
%c[255,1,255,255]ï %c[default]7.62x39 mm API
 
7.62mm modernized Kalashnikov assault rifle (6P1). The AKM was adopted in 1959 to replace the AK. The modernization process included lighter stamped components, increased effective range, reliability, and ease of use. The rifle can also mount newer muzzle brakes/silencers and grenade launchers. 
The renowned Kalashnikov action ensures great reliability, and a great number of AKM variants are still in service with the Russian Army and MVD.

%c[255,1,255,255]Ammunition type: %c[default] \n%c[255,1,255,255]ï %c[default] .45 ACP FMJ-main \n%c[255,1,255,255]ï %c[default] .45 ACP Hydro-reinforced self-loading pistol .45 caliber (11. 43x23 mm) M1911, designed by Browning and produced by Colt adopted by the US Army in 1911. In 1926 the gun was modernised, and continued to serve under the symbol of Colt M1911 A1 Government Model. The "Government Model" was in service until 1985, becoming the longest-lived army pistol. In the Russian Empire, Colts were used in the police and gendarme corps, were purchased in the First World War (English ORDER), and were supplied to the White Movement. Captured pistols entered service with the Red Army. During the Second World War, Colts were supplied to the USSR under lend-lease. "Old Man Colt" has a cult status in the United States and is still allowed to use. Significant weight and size, the small capacity of the magazine is to some extent compensated by a powerful cartridge with a low muzzle velocity and therefore the 1911 is often used to create "silent" variants.

Universal self-loading pistol the Heckler and Koch Universal Selbstlade Pistole was developed in 1993. One of the distinctive features is a wide variety of modifications-pistols can be converted to different calibers in the field by replacing the bolt, magazine and barrel with special Conversion Kits. In 1995, the 9x19-mm version was adopted by the German Armed Forces under the designation P8 (Pistole 8), and in 1996 the modification .45 caliber (11, 43x23 mm) was adopted by a special unit of the US Navy SEAL under the designation Mk23 Model. 0. On the basis of the USP series pistols, numerous civilian and special variants were created. German quality and reliability - The Heckler-Koch USP is currently considered the most accurate self-loading pistol of the forty-fifth caliber.

%c[255,1,255,255]Ammunition type: %c[default] \n%c[255,1,255,255]ï %c[default] 9x19 mm Para-main \n%c[255,1,255,255]ï %c[default] 9x19 mm +P+ - increased power \ psamozaryadny pistol caliber 9x19 mm FN Browning Hi-Power 1935. Designed by J. M. Browning in 1926, but his death prevented him from personally transferring the model to the production of Fabrique Nacional. In the early 30s of the XX century. this weapon, after some refinement by Didier Sav, began to be produced under the name "Browning mod. 1935". Later, the gun received its own name "High Power", reflecting the high capacity of the store. During the Second World War, occupied Belgium continued production under the new designation Pistole 640 (b) for the Wehrmacht. The M1935 was also widely used in other armies. Currently, it is also in service with many countries. Reliable, powerful, with good accuracy of shooting "the last Browning" is deservedly considered one of the best pistols of the XX century.

%c[255,1,255,255]Ammunition type: %c[default] \n%c[255,1,255,255]ï %c[default] 9x19 mm Para-main \n%c[255,1,255,255]ï %c[default] 9x19 mm +P+ - increased power \ psamozaryadny pistol caliber 9x19 mm Parabellum system Borchardt-Luger sample 1908. It was in service until 1942, becoming a symbol of German weapons. The main advantage is the high accuracy of shooting, which has become a kind of standard for modern pistols.

%c[255,1,255,255]Ammunition type: %c[default] 
%c[255,1,255,255]ï %c[default] 7,62x25 mm TT - main 
%c[255,1,255,255]ï %c[default] 7,62x25 mm PS - armor-piercing 
7,62-mm self-loading pistol mod.1933 (Tula, Tokareva; 56 ó A-132) - the first army self-loading pistol of the USSR, designed to replace both the obsolete revolver Nagant obr 1895, and various imported pistols that were in service with the Red Army. For its time, the TT was a fairly advanced weapon, powerful and reliable, easy to maintain and repair, convenient for concealed carry. Despite the adoption of the Makarov pistol in 1951, the TT was in service with the Soviet army until the early 1960s, in law enforcement agencies until the mid-1970s, and in VOHR-e and other organizations, as well as special operations groups ó until the 1990s. The "dashing 90's" TT became famous as a "killer weapon" due to the high penetration effect of the bullet, as well as due to the fact that many units of this weapon were not included in the bullet library, which made it difficult to identify and trace the history of use.

%c[255,1,255,255]Ammunition type: %c[default] \n%c[255,1,255,255]ï %c[default] 9x18 mm PM-main \n%c[255,1,255,255]ï %c[default] 9x18 mm PMM-reinforced \ n9x18 mm Makarov self-loading pistol (56-A-125) was developed in 1948 as a result of a competition for the development of a pistol for officers of the Soviet Army more compact and safe to handle than the TT. The PM has served as a personal weapon in the Soviet and post-Soviet armed forces and militia since 1951. Extremely reliable, easy to use and maintain. Having at the same time an accurate battle for its class, "Makar" is one of the best representatives of compact self-defense weapons. Its disadvantages are the small capacity of the magazine and the low combat effectiveness of the bullet.

%c[255,1,255,255]Ammunition type: %c[default] \n%c[255,1,255,255]ï %c[default] 9x18 mm PM-main \n%c[255,1,255,255]ï %c[default] 9x18 mm PMM-reinforced \ n9x18 mm self-loading pistol silent (6P9) was developed on the basis of the Makarov pistol for arming army intelligence groups and KGB personnel of the USSR and adopted in 1967. PB uses an integral silencer, and unlike most similar systems, the silencer of the sound of a shot is made collapsible from two parts. This solution allows you to carry and store the gun with the front part of the silencer (nozzle) removed, and quickly install the nozzle on the weapon before use. At the same time, the gun retains the ability to fire safely for the shooter when the nozzle is removed, which is important in critical situations.

%c[255,1,255,255]Ammunition type: %c[default] \n%c[255,1,255,255]ï %c[default] 9x18 mm PM-main \n%c[255,1,255,255]ï %c[default] 9x18 mm PMM-reinforced \ n9x18 mm automatic pistol "silent" APB (AO-44, product 6P13). It was developed in the early 70's by the designer A. S. Neugodov on the basis of the Stechkin automatic pistol withdrawn from the army. It was adopted in 1972 for intelligence and special units of the Soviet Army, as well as employees of special units of the Ministry of Internal Affairs and the KGB of the USSR. It differs from the APS in the presence of an elongated barrel with a device for attaching a silencer and a chamber for transferring powder gases, which fits into the dimensions of the shutter casing. If necessary, the APB can be fired in bursts. In this case, it is desirable to use a regular stock. APB has received great recognition from the special services for its significant firepower and combat effectiveness, and continues to be used today.

%c[255,1,255,255]Ammunition:
ï %c[default]9x18mm PM
%c[255,1,255,255]ï %c[default]9x18mm PBM
%c[255,1,255,255]ï %c[default]9x18mm PMM
 
9x18mm automatic pistol OZ-33 "Pernach" is a russian pistol, which was developed in the mid of 1990s by group of designers of the Central Design Bureau of Sport and Hunting Weapons headed by Stechkin for APS pistol replacement. It was reviously known as AP SBZ-2 (automatic pistol designed by Stechkin, Baltzer, Zinchenko). Some of OZ-33 is used by various units of the Russian Ministry of Internal Affairs. Compared with "Stechkin" pistol OZ-33 has simplified design and improved handling.

%c[255,1,255,255]Ammunition type: %c[default] 
%c[255,1,255,255]ï %c[default] 9x18 mm PM - main 
%c[255,1,255,255]ï %c[default] 9x18 mm PMM - reinforced 
9x18 mm submachine gun PP-91 Design by Evgeny dragunov created in the early 1990s by order of the Ministry of Internal Affairs of the Russian Federation on the basis of an earlier PP-71, developed in the 1970s for the Soviet Army as part of the ROC "Bouquet" (small-sized PP for the army). Currently, "Cedars" are widely used in the power structures of the Russian Federation.

%c[255,1,255,255]Munition type: %c[default] \n%c[255,1,255,255]ï %c[default] 9x19 mm Para - main \n%c[255,1,255,255]ï %c[default] 9x19 mm +P+ - high-power \Ô9ı19 mm submachine gun PP-2000 was developed by the Tula KBP team under leadership of V. P. Griazev and A. G. shipunova in the framework of the ROC defense Ministry, "Bakinets" in connection with the adoption of the new Russian army pistol cartridges. Currently, PP-2000 is used by separate units of the Ministry of Internal Affairs of the Russian Federation, adopted by the Federal Bailiff Service.

%c[255,1,255,255]Type of ammunition: %c[default] 
%c[255,1,255,255]ï %c[default] 9x19 mm Para - main 
%c[255,1,255,255]ï %c[default] 9x19 mm +P+ - increased power 
9x19 mm self-loading pistol gsh-18 was developed in the late 1990s in the Tula Instrument Design Bureau under the guidance of well - known designers of weapons (mainly air guns) V. P. Gryazev and A. G. Shipunova. The number 18 in the name indicates the capacity of the store. The advantages of the gsh-18 include a very small weight for its class, a large magazine capacity, a low location of the barrel relative to the shooter's hand, and good accuracy of fire. The disadvantages of "our answer to the Glock" include a low manufacturing culture and a kind of descent.

%c[255,1,255,255]Ammunition type: %c[default] \n%c[255,1,255,255]ï %c[default] 9x18 mm PM-main \n%c[255,1,255,255]ï %c[default] 9x18 mm PMM-reinforced \ n9x18 mm self-loading pistol "Fort" was developed to replace the PM in the early 1990s by order of the Ministry of Internal Affairs of Ukraine and adopted, but in fact mass rearmament did not occur. During development we relied on the experience of the Czech arms firm Ceska Zbrojovka. Serial production began in 1998 (barrels were supplied from the Czech Republic until 2002). Pistols of the first years of production had serious problems with reliability. After receiving a Czech CNC machine tools, the proportion of marriage has declined significantly. The Fort-17 modification features a lightweight polymer frame made of fiberglass-reinforced impact-resistant polyamide and a "Picatinny" mount under the gun barrel. A number of "samopals from Vinnytsia" were at the disposal of the Ministry of Internal Affairs of the Russian Federation, when in March 2014 the Simferopol detachment "Berkut" continued to serve as a unit of the Ministry of Internal Affairs of Russia. It will be able to give a head start to "Makar" only at the expense of a more capacious store.

The Desert Eagle self-loading pistol was developed as a hunting weapon for civilians in 1983 in the United States by Magnum Research with subsequent refinement by the Israeli company Israel Military Industries. A real gun for real heroes: it looks intimidating, but that's where its practical value ends: The Desert Eagle has excessive weight, recoil, and muzzle flash. The gun is very sensitive to care and has never been tested to work in difficult conditions.

%c[255,1,255,255]Ammunition type: %c[default] \n%c[255,1,255,255]ï %c[default] 9x19 mm Para-main \n%c[255,1,255,255]ï %c[default] 9x19 mm +P+ - high power \ pavtomatic pistol caliber 9x19 mm Glock 18C. It was created by the Austrian company Glock GmbH on the basis of Glock 17 for arming special forces of the army and police and is distinguished primarily by the presence of a shooting mode translator. The special feature of the "Glock" design is the frame and some other parts made of heat-resistant polyamide and the "Safe Action" trigger mechanism-an integrated safety system that consists of three independently operating automatic fuses. Another feature - for the production of two or more shots in a row, you do not need to completely release the trigger. Thanks to its successful design, the gun has become widely used all over the world. Various modifications of the Glock are in service with the army, police and special services of more than 30 countries, approved by NATO as one of the main models of personal small arms.

%c[255,1,255,255]Ammunition type: %c[default] \n%c[255,1,255,255]ï %c[default] .45 ACP-primary \n%c[255,1,255,255]ï %c[default] .45 ACP "Hydroshock" - improved \ ningram MAC M10 (Military Armament Corporation Model 10) caliber .45 ACP (11. 43x23 mm). The M10 was designed by Gordon B. Ingram in 1964, as a submachine gun suitable for concealed carry. The main idea behind the design is maximum simplicity and low cost. A high rate of fire provides significant firepower at short distances, but in combination with a small mass and a short barrel leads to a significant dispersion of bullets when firing. Thanks to a powerful cartridge with a low muzzle velocity, the MAC is often used to create "silent" variants.

3-line (7.62-mm) Nagant system of the sample of 1895 (56-N-121). The Nagant M1895 was developed by Belgian gunsmiths brothers Emil and Leon Nagant. It was adopted by the Russian Army in 1895. According to the terms of the competition, Leon Nagan gave his invention to the full ownership of the Russian government. After a small modernization, production was established at the Imperial Tula Arms Factory. The design peculiarity is looming on the barrel drum, the crucial issue of obduracy and thereby significantly increasing the "power battle" and stopping power of the bullet without increasing caliber, which helped to keep the low recoil, increasing accuracy and shooting accuracy. \blagodarya simplicity of design, simplicity of operation and reliability, "revolver" as a staff of handguns Russian, the red and Soviet army successfully passed the Russo-Japanese, First world, Civil, Finnish and the Great Patriotic war. For the Soviet partisans, modifications were produced for the cartridge 7, 62x25 TT. For the special forces of the Red Army, the NKVD OKB developed the "bramit device".

Automatic pistol-carbine Mauser (German: Mauser Construction 96 Model 712 "Schnellfeuer") mod.1932 under the cartridge 7,63x25 mm Mauser (later adopted by the Red Army in a slightly modified form as 7,62x25 mm TT). Officially, it was not in service anywhere, but in many countries (in particular, in the Russian Empire and, subsequently, the USSR, "Comrade Mauser" was adopted for partial armament of special purpose units). The design made it possible to conduct effective fire at an unprecedented distance for pistols ó up to 200 m (using a holster-butt).

7, 62-mm AEK-973 (6P68). Developed according to the scheme of "balanced automation" in the 1980s at the Kovrov Mechanical Plant under the leadership of S. I. Koksharov on the basis of the Konstantinov system. Being more complex than "conventional" automation with a gas engine, the scheme of "balanced automation" is still simpler than the AN-94, built according to the carriage scheme with the accumulation of recoil momentum. In the 1990s, the AEK was modified and produced in small quantities for the needs of the Ministry of Internal Affairs and other law enforcement agencies of Russia until 2006, when the production of military products was completely curtailed at KMZ. All production of such products was transferred to the Kovrov plant named after Degtyarev. At the same time, work on further improvement of the AEC was launched at the zid, and in 2013-2014, deeply modernized versions of the A545 and A762 were transferred to state tests under the Ratnik program.

%c[255,1,255,255]Ammunition type: %c[default] \n%c[255,1,255,255]ï %c[default] 5, 45x39 mm PS-main \n%c[255,1,255,255]ï %c[default] 5, 45x39 mm PS-armor-piercing \ n5,45-mm Nikonov machine gun mod. 1994 (6P33) developed within the framework of the competition program "Abakan" according to the "carriage scheme" with a shifted recoil pulse. The second cartridge is fed into the barrel during the rollback of the barrel from a special intermediate chamber. Immediately after sending the second shot is fired, which significantly increases the accuracy when shooting in short bursts, especially from unstable positions. The AN94 was planned to replace Kalashnikov assault rifles in the army, but currently, for a number of reasons, it is in service only with some special units of the army and the Ministry of Internal Affairs. The main drawback is the high complexity of the design, increased requirements for the gun culture of the shooter.

%c[255,1,255,255]ï %c[default] 7,62x54 mm 7H14-sniper armor-piercing \ptrekhlineynaya sniper rifle mod. 1891/30 gg. (56-V-222A) design S. N. Mosin. Adopted by the Russian Army in 1891, and modernized in 1930, the dragoon version "continued service" in the Red, and then the Soviet Army until the end of the 1940s, becoming one of the most popular models of infantry weapons. For modifications to the sniper version, starting in the 1930s, rifles with the best combat accuracy were selected from the gross ones. As a sniper, the "three-line" was used until the adoption of the SVD.

The machine gun was used from a universal machine of the Kolesnikov system (the wheels and shield were removed, the shoulder pad was installed, and the rear support of the machine was removed, forming a tripod) as an infantry support weapon, it was installed on armored vehicles and small ships.

Developed on the basis of the RM sports rifle. A special feature is the chassis system based on the frame-support rail rifle technology and the ability to use it in the Arctic. It is equipped with an optical sight of variable multiplicity Schmidt and Bender PM II. The Parker-Hale folding, height-adjustable, removable bipod is also included as standard.

5,56-mm assault rifle G36 company Heckler and Koch GmbH built with the widest use of plastics on the schematic diagram of the Kalashnikov assault rifle pseudo-modular for example, all parts are connected with pins for quick disassembly. The main advantages of the "soldier's bride" are ergonomics and extremely low recoil, which ensure high accuracy and accuracy of shooting. The most serious disadvantages are low reliability in intensive shooting and the complexity of maintenance in the field. \ n"Lego-Gewehr" was adopted by the Bundeswehr in 1995, its various variants are exported to the United States and a number of other countries.

5. 56-mm automatic rifle XM16E1-the legendary "black evil rifle". \ nm16 and its modifications (Colt-AR15 family), which have been in service since the Vietnam War, is one of the most common models of small arms in the world and is second only to the Kalashnikov assault rifle in popularity.

5, 56 mm Enfield SA-80/L85A2 assault rifle. The British complex Small Arms for 1980, "small arms of the 1980s" was to become a universal weapon suitable for both "linear" units, and for paratroopers and armored vehicle crews and replace three main types of small arms that were in service with the British Army: the SLR rifle, the 9 mm Sterling submachine gun and the 7.62 mm GPMG single machine gun. Thanks to the "bullpup" scheme, the length of the L85 is a third less than the SLR, while its trunk is slightly inferior to the trunk of its predecessor. 
The most serious drawback is low reliability. Adopted in 1984 and repeatedly upgraded. Various variants are exported to a number of other countries.

%c[255,1,255,255]Ammunition type: %c[default] \n%c[255,1,255,255]ï %c[default] 5, 56x45 mm FMJ-main \n%c[255,1,255,255]ï %c[default] 5, 56x45 mm AP-armor-piercing \ n5,56-mm modular rifle and grenade launcher Fabrique Nationale Herstal F2000. Developed in the late 90s, mass-produced from 2001-2002. Polymers are used as housing materials, the handguard is plastic, easily removable, in place of which various additional modules can be installed. The optical sight module is attached to the receiver unit using a universal tire. \ New feature-full "two-sided" thanks to the frontal extraction of spent cartridges.

PBS-1 suppressor (6Ch12). Designed for noiseless and flameless fire from 7.62mm Kalashnikov rifles. Developed by NII-61 (now TsNIITochMash) and adopted in 1962 for the Soviet army's reconnaisance, sabotage, and special-purpose units. Replaces the standard muzzle brake. If using this suppressor, subsonic (7.62x39 US) rounds must be used.

PBS-4 suppressor. Developed by NII-61 (now TsNIITochMash) and adopted in 1980 for the Soviet army's reconnaisance, sabotage, and special-purpose units. Designed for noiseless and flameless fire from the AKS74U, as part of the "Canary" (6S1) complex with a silent grenade launcher. Replaces the standard muzzle brake. Can be installed on the AKS74U and its variants. If using this suppressor, subsonic (5.45x39 US) rounds must be used.
TGP-A suppressor. Designed to muffle firing sound and suppress muzzle flash on 5.45mm Kalashnikov rifles. Replaces the standard muzzle device.
ATG tactical silencer for assault rifles. Reduces the loudness and visible manifestation of shooting from 5.56mm Kalashnikov rifles. Can be mounted in place of muzzle compensator.

TGP-V tactical suppressor for assault rifles. Can be used for position masking (almost no flare) and reducing sound impact to the user during firing from 7,62-mm Dragunov sniper rifle. Can be mounted to default SVD flame arrestor.

Complex muzzle device of SVU. Performs the functions of a muzzle brake, absorbing up to 40% of the energy of the recoil, compensator-weight (reducing barrel vibrations and shifting forward the center of gravity), flame and low noise firing device. Provides a reduction in the sound level of the shot by 10-12% compared to the SVD and disperses the sound of the shot in such a way that it becomes impossible to determine the exact position of the shooter.
Silencer-flame extinguisher tactical GEMTECH G5 5.56 mm NATO. Designed to reduce the sound and flame of the shot. The multimount adapter is included.
GEMTECH multimount 9mm tactical flame suppressor. Designed to reduce the sound and flame of the shot. Included is a compensator adapter.
An artisanal "silencer" assembled in the Zone by some craftsman. Included-adapters for the main calibers.
Nozzles for conducting silent and flameless firing from PB.
Nozzle for conducting silent and flameless shooting from the APB.

"Bramit device" (according to the modern terminology of PBS/TGP). Created in the Special Design Bureau of the NKVD by the Mitin brothers. A model designed to be mounted on a revolver of the Nagant system was developed in 1929. "Silencer" was widely used during the Great Patriotic War by soldiers of special forces of the Red Army and NKVD, as well as partisans.
A device for silent and flameless shooting from a 9-mm military sniper complex.

Trijicon ACOGÆ (Advanced Combat Optical Gunsight) scope. Does not require batteries - reticle illumination is done via optical fibers (tritium illumination is used in low-light conditions). Designed to be mounted on standard NATO picatinny rails. 4x magnification.
SUSAT L9A1 (Sight Unit, Small Arms, Trilux) scope. Tritium illumination is used in low-light conditions. Its integrated mount is designed for the L85 rifle. 4x magnification.

Optical module-sighting device for the Fabrique Nationale Herstal F2000 rifle and grenade launcher system. Integrated mounting involves installation on a standard universal bar. Visible magnification of 1.6 times.

PSO-1 (6Ts1) sniper scope. Designed for aimed fire in day or night conditions, at illuminated or backlit targets. The sight features a rangefinder grind, allowing for range estimation based on horizontal measurements. The design and housing bracket allows the optic to be installed on any weapon with SVD-like "dovetail" mount. 4x magnification.

USP-1 "Tulip" (1P29) unified combat scope. Designed for aimed fire in day or night conditions, at illuminated or backlit targets. Does not require batteries (tritium illumination is used in low-light conditions). The design and housing bracket allows the optic to be installed on any weapon with a Soviet-standard "dovetail" mount. 4x magnification.

EKP "Kobra" open collimator sight with electronic controls for brightness and reticle type. It was designed to improve the speed of shooting at emerging and moving targets, in daylight or low-light conditions. The design and housing bracket allows the optic to be installed on any weapon with a Soviet-standard "dovetail" mount.

NSPU-3 (1PN51) unified night-vision gunsight. Designed for battlefield observation and aimed fire from lightweight small arms in daylight or low-light conditions. The design and housing bracket allows the optic to be installed on any weapon with a Soviet-standard "dovetail" mount. 3.46x magnification

L-3 EOTech 552.A65 Military Series weapon sight (Holographic Weapon Sight, sight mark is formed as a result of difraction of laser radiation on the hologram). Was designed for mounting on the standard NATO mount - Picatinny rail. Can be used together with optical magnifiers. Has lower bright mode for using with night vision devices.

Pancratic sniper scope "Hyperon" (1P59). Was designed for sniper firing during day and night. Provides automatic input of the aiming angle when measuring distance to the target. Can be attached on the standard Soviet mount - "dovetail" side rail.

The collimator sight of closed type Aimpoint Micro H-1. Designed to increase the effectiveness of shooting at emerging and moving targets with a lack of time in daytime and twilight lighting conditions. The design of the bracket combined with the body allows you to install the sight on a weapon with a standard for NATO countries mount-Picatinny rail. It has a low-brightness mode for use in conjunction with night vision devices.

Sight original Colt 3X20 AR15/M16 scope. Designed for mounting on the Carry Handle Scope Mount of the M16 automatic rifle and its modifications (AR15 family). %c[255,1,255,255]Visible magnification-variable from 1.5 to 3 times.

Rifle scope us Optics SR-6. A special feature of U.S. Optics is the production of a custom sight. The customer can choose the housing, mesh type and other options and accessories. Designed for installation on the standard for NATO countries mount-Picatinny rail (Picatinny rail). %c[255,1,255,255]Visible magnification-variable from 1.5 to 6 times.

Army / Navy Portable Visual Search is a portable monocular night vision device. Designed for installation on the standard for NATO countries mount - Picatinny rail (Picatinny rail) with an adapter. It is possible to use the device attached to the combat helmet.

The IR NV thermal imager makes it possible to detect objects in smoke-filled conditions, during heavy precipitation, and even through intermittent obstacles (for example, dense thickets). It is possible to use the device attached to the combat helmet.

Optical magnifier attachment EOTech G33. STS Magnifier. Designed for installation on the standard for NATO countries mount-Picatinny rail (Picatinny rail). It can be used in conjunction with EOTech collimator sights. Visible magnification of 3x.

Army / Navy Portable Visual Search is a portable monocular night vision device. Designed for installation on the standard for NATO countries mount - Picatinny rail (Picatinny rail) with an adapter. It can be used in conjunction with EOTech or Trijicon ACOG collimator sights.

The IR NV thermal imager makes it possible to detect objects in smoke-filled conditions, during heavy precipitation, and even through intermittent obstacles (for example, dense thickets). Designed for installation on the standard for NATO countries mount - Picatinny rail (Picatinny rail) with an adapter. It can be used in conjunction with EOTech or Trijicon ACOG collimator sights.

Optical sniper scope PSO-1M2-1. Was designed for sniper firing during day and night. Has specific range grid that allows to account horizontal corrections. Can be attached on the standard Soviet mount - "dovetail" side rail. 4x magnification.

The sight is shortened PU. Designed for use in the sniper version of the Tokarev self-loading rifle, where the use of a longer and heavier sight was technically difficult. However, the front's need for sniper weapons was covered by the Mosin shaft rifles selected for accuracy of fire, on which the PU was installed on a bracket developed by D. M. Kochetov with a so-called side "high wall". Visible magnification of 3.5 times.
Optical sight for 4x34. Designed for use in the sniper version of "Thunderstorms". The apparent increase in 4 times.

Grenade launcher optical sight PGO-7V (1OP19-3). Designed for conducting targeted shooting in the daytime and at night on glowing and illuminated targets. A special feature of the sight is a rangefinder grid for a target with a height of 2.7 m (tank), as well as a scale of remote and lateral corrections. The design of the bracket combined with the body allows you to install the sight on a weapon with a special dovetail mount. The apparent increase of 2.7 times.
Under-barrel tactical flashlight 2PS "Tick" with integrated laser designator "Anti-aircraft gun". Designed for installation on the standard for NATO countries mount-Picatinny rail (Picatinny rail).

The MTK-83 adapter bracket is a base for installing sights with a standard Picatinny rail mount for NATO countries on weapons with a standard Soviet dovetail mount. The design allows you to remove and install sights on weapons without losing alignment.

Universal Scope Mount FAB DEFENSE adapter bracket is a base for installing sights with a standard Picatinny rail mount for NATO countries on the under-barrel rail of pistols. The design allows you to remove and install sights on weapons without losing alignment.
"Dovetail" side mount - a device for installing Warsaw Pact scopes. The design allows for quick detachment and reattachment without losing zero.

The HK G36C carrying handle is a base for mounting sights with a standard Picatinny rail mount for NATO countries. The design allows you to remove and install the handle on the HK G36 instead of the standard one (with the HKV sighting complex consisting of a 3.5 x ZF optical sight and a collimator RV) without loss of alignment.
Handle for carrying SA-80. The design allows you to remove and install the handle instead of the standard 4X SUSAT optical sight.

7.62x39mm double-stack box magazine, 30-round capacity for the AKM (6L10). Interchangeable with 40-round box magazines and 75-round drum magazines. Compatible with whole line of AKM-series assault carbines.

7.62x39mm double-stack box magazine, 40-round capacity for the RPK. Interchangeable with 30-round (6L10) box magazines and 75-round drum magazines. Compatible with whole line of AKM-series assault carbines.
7.62x39mm drum magazine, 75-round capacity for the RPK. Interchangeable with 40-round and 30-round (6L10) box magazines. Compatible with whole line of AKM-series assault carbines.

5.45x39mm double-stack box magazine, 30-round capacity for the AK74 (6L20). Interchangeable with 45-round (6L18) and 60-round (6L31) box magazines. Compatible with whole line of AK74-series assault carbines.

5.45x39mm double-stack box magazine, 45-round capacity for the RPK74 (6L18). Interchangeable with 30-round (6L20) and 60-round (6L31) box magazines. Compatible with whole line of AK74-series assault carbines.

5.45x39mm quad-stack box magazine, 60-round capacity for the AK74M and AK105 (6L31). Interchangeable with 30-round (6L20) and 45-round (6L18) box magazines. Compatible with whole line of AK74-series assault carbines.
5.56x45mm box magazine, 30-round capacity for the AK101 and AK102 (6L29). Made of fiberglass-reinforced plastic with steel feed lips and locking lug.

HK 215098 sector-type box magazine with a double-row staggered arrangement of 30 rounds of 5. 56x45 mm caliber. Designed for the HK G36. For flow control, it is made of transparent plastic. It has special mounts that allow you to combine stores in pairs to speed up reloading.

Beta C-Mag magazine with 100 5.56x45 mm cartridges. Developed by Jim Sullivan. Made of plastic reinforced with glass fiber, equipped with metal neck and cover. The latest version of the magazine is available with a transparent backing to allow the user to see the number of rounds remaining in the magazine.
Box magazine of selector type with two rows of 10 7.62x54mm cartridges, placed in checkboard pattern.
Experimental box magazine of selector type with two rows of 20 7.62x54mmR cartridges, placed in checkboard pattern. Compatible with full-sized SVD rifle.
Box magazine 6L24 sector type with a double-row staggered arrangement of 10 rounds of 9x39 mm caliber. Interchangeable with a 6L25 box magazine for 20 rounds.
Box magazine 6L25 sector type with a double-row staggered arrangement of 20 rounds of 9x39 mm caliber. Interchangeable with a 6L24 box magazine for 10 rounds.
Box magazine 9A91/994 sector type with a double-row staggered arrangement of 20 rounds of 9x39 mm caliber.
Box magazine OTS-14-4 sector type with a double-row staggered arrangement of 20 rounds of 9x39 mm caliber.
Box magazine SR-3M sector type with a double-row staggered arrangement of 30 rounds of 9x39 mm caliber.
Box magazine Glock sector type with a double-row staggered arrangement of 17 rounds of 9x19 mm caliber.
Enlarged Glock sector-type box magazine with a double-row staggered arrangement of 31 rounds of 9x19 mm caliber.
Box magazine of sector type with a double-row staggered arrangement of 6 rounds of 12x76 mm caliber. Interchangeable with a box magazine with an increased capacity of 10 rounds.
Box magazine of increased capacity of the sector type with a double-row staggered arrangement of 10 rounds of 12x76 mm caliber. Interchangeable with a 6-round box magazine.
Box magazine of increased capacity of the sector type with a double-row staggered arrangement of 10 rounds of 12x76 mm caliber. Interchangeable with a 4-round box magazine.
Magazine extension for 4 rounds of 12x76 mm caliber.
Magazine extension for 2 rounds of 12x76 mm caliber.
The 870MCS system kit includes a 14-inch replacement barrel, a pistol grip or stock, and a magazine extension.

Tactical inclined handle Magpul Angled Fore Grip for installation on the standard for NATO countries mount-Picatinny rail. Improves weapon control, accelerates stabilization after a shot, helping to reduce recoil and withdrawal from the target line. The angular grip position of the handle is more ergonomic compared to the vertical ones.
Tactical vertical handle with mounting for mounting on the PBS. Improves weapon control, accelerates stabilization after a shot, helping to reduce recoil and withdrawal from the target line.
Custom ¿ Kit for 10x series of Kalashnikov rifles. Includes telescopic butt, pistol anatomic handgrip and handguard with lower standard NATO mount (Picatinny rail).
Backplate/shock absorber for underbarrel grenade launcher. Reduces recoil during firing from grenade launcher. Can be attached to the butt of the rifle and fixed with strap.
Unadjustable cheek rest, can be attached on SVD. Makes sniper fire management more convenient. Can be mounted on the butt and fixed on it with a lock.
The butt is included in the membership of APB. It serves for the convenience of the action of the gun when shooting in automatic mode.

As the butt of the "Mauser", its holster is used, made of walnut wood, on the front section of which there is a steel insert with a protrusion and a locking mechanism for joining the pistol handle. The holster-butt is indispensable for targeted shooting, especially in automatic mode.
Removable folding shoulder rest 9A-91. When folded, it is located on the cover of the receiver. It can be installed on the VSK-94 instead of the standard skeleton-type butt for ease of wearing.
Plastic-metal removable butt VSK-94 skeletal type. It can be installed on the 9A-91 instead of the standard folding shoulder rest and pistol grip for easy targeting, especially in automatic mode.
Heckler and Koch Conversion Kit is designed for switching of USP pistol caliber with new barrel, magazine and shutter.
"Super SOG Bowie" the knife 5, a group of US special Forces. Developed during the Vietnam war and still actively used in covert operations green berets.
M9 Bayonet - bayonet of the U.S. armed forces. Developed in 1980 as a multi-purpose military tool and was adopted for service in 1984. Equipped with a case which is set for survival.
Upgraded military bayonet 6X4. Various species is manned since 1965 AKM/AKMS, SVD, AK74/AKS74.
Military bayonet 6X2 (56-X-212). Adopted with the Kalashnikov rifle in 1955. Design allows use as a military knife.
Crowbar with stamped marking "Manufactured for Black Mesa"
A normal piece of pipe. So a weapon, but if you try hard, you can cut down the person.

Sports and hunting crossbow, modified by order of the Doctor for the use of special arrows with a paralyzing substance.

Yukon NVB Tracker 3x42 night vision binoculars. The binoculars have a viewing distance of 250 meters, and the built-in PULSEô IR illuminator significantly improves the quality of observation at night at a distance of up to 150 meters and provides visibility in complete darkness. Visible magnification of 3x.
A small Hiking backpack. Made from rubberized fabric, so wet. In this you can store your valuables somewhere in a secluded place - the cache will be different.

Dosimeter-radiometer RKS-20.03 "Pripyat". The first and chief instrument for the Stalker who doesn't want to lose your hair on the second day of stay in the Area. The device measures the power of ionizing radiation. In the presence of radiation beeps.\n To work you need to activate it by placing the device on the belt.
Detection of abnormal activity of the first generation "Response". Reacts with a light signal when approaching an abnormal formation. The distance is determined by the frequency of the light signal.
Detector of abnormal activity of the second generation "Scout". It is equipped with an LED display board to display the direction to the abnormal formation and the distance to it.

Detector-scanner of the third generation "Search". The search mode is activated by a switch on the front side of the device. If there is a GPS module, it can transmit the coordinates of nearby anomalous formations to a special screen.

Instruction on small business - the traditional for Soviet and Russian army the name of the manual device of small arms use and maintenance. NSD is the official document for training personnel in the use of weapons.
